column4: So I do what I thought was the sensible thing and ran apt-get upgrade and now my machine is unbootable. The last message on the screen is fsck caliming /dev/sda2 is clean. Even when I click the recovery mode option I get the same message. How can I determine what broke?

Other then that I wish I knew. This was a clean install 3 weeks ago. What log file should I be looking in. The fact that even recovery mode hangs leads me to suspect grub is screwed. What could have happened.
What log file would tell me what happened. Ubuntu Kinda changed everything about the way it bots so I don't know.
How do I go single user? Is it like "linux 1"?  at boot? The video is really slow.
So why can't I just hit "C" linux single?
what happens when you try to do that?
is there a recovery mode option?
iptables can't be stopped or reset.  It is a kernel feature, not a service
there are methods to change the rules in iptables or clear them though, but I forget how
since when? I've always been able to create new rules then restart iptables.
I mean that it can't be restarted in the same way as regular services
Whats the real way to configure iptables rules?
I recall adding some scripts to the directories under /etc/network/ to do save iptables rules when interfaces go down and reload them when they go up
I think ufw might save rules
if-up.d is a directory, not a file
I have if-pre-up.d containing a script to restore iptables, and if-post-down.d containing a script to save the rules
